owl:Ontology.terms:description: The ontology aims at formalize basic notions of the Unified Foundational Ontology, part A - structural models.
owl:Ontology.terms:title: Unified Foundational Ontology - A

owl:Class.terms:description: A «category» represents a rigid and relationally independent mixin, i.e., a dispersive universal that aggregates essential properties which are common to different substance sortals. For example, the category RationalEntity as a generalization of Person and IntelligentAgent.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Category
Kategorie

owl:Axiom.owl:annotatedTarget: A «category» represents a rigid and relationally independent mixin, i.e., a dispersive universal that aggregates essential properties which are common to different substance sortals. For example, the category RationalEntity as a generalization of Person and IntelligentAgent.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Collective
owl:Class.skos:definition: A «collective» represents a substance sortal whose instances are collectives, i.e., they are collections of complexes that have a uniform structure. Examples include a deck of cards, a forest, a group of people, a pile of bricks. Collectives can typically relate to complexes via a constitution relation. For example, a pile of bricks that constitutes a wall, a group of people that constitutes a football team. In this case, the collectives typically have an extensional principle of identity, in contrast to the complexes they constitute. For instance, The Beatles was in a given world w constituted by the collective {John, Paul, George, Pete} and in another world w’ constituted by the collective {John, Paul, George, Ringo}. The replacement of Pete Best by Ringo Star does not alter the identity of the band, but creates a numerically different group of people.

owl:Axiom.owl:annotatedTarget: A «collective» represents a substance sortal whose instances are collectives, i.e., they are collections of complexes that have a uniform structure. Examples include a deck of cards, a forest, a group of people, a pile of bricks. Collectives can typically relate to complexes via a constitution relation. For example, a pile of bricks that constitutes a wall, a group of people that constitutes a football team. In this case, the collectives typically have an extensional principle of identity, in contrast to the complexes they constitute. For instance, The Beatles was in a given world w constituted by the collective {John, Paul, George, Pete} and in another world w’ constituted by the collective {John, Paul, George, Ringo}. The replacement of Pete Best by Ringo Star does not alter the identity of the band, but creates a numerically different group of people.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Endurant
Endurant
owl:Class.skos:definition: Endurant is an entity existing in time. Endurants participate in events and can have tropes. Theirs state can change over time.
Endurant je prvek jenž existuje v čase. Enduranty se mohou účastnit událostí a mít závislé prvky.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Individual
Individuál
owl:Class.skos:definition: Individual is any entity, which denotes a unique concept, which cannot be used for typing
Individuálem je prvek, který označuje jednotlivost, nelze jej použít pro typování, klasifikaci, jiných prvků.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Druh
Kind
owl:Class.skos:definition: A kind represents a substance sortal whose instances are functional complexes. Examples include instances of Natural Kinds (such as Person, Dog, Tree) and of artifacts (Chair, Car, Television).

owl:Axiom.owl:annotatedTarget: A kind represents a substance sortal whose instances are functional complexes. Examples include instances of Natural Kinds (such as Person, Dog, Tree) and of artifacts (Chair, Car, Television).

owl:Class.terms:description: Mixin Type represents the general properties of all mixins, i.e., non-sortals (or dispersive universals).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Mixin Type
Typ mixinu

owl:Axiom.owl:annotatedTarget: Mixin Type represents the general properties of all mixins, i.e., non-sortals (or dispersive universals).
owl:Axiom.rdfs:comment: definition partially reused from Mixin Class

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Object
Objekt
owl:Class.skos:definition: Object is any identifiable endurant entity existence of which is not directly dependent on an existence of another entity.
owl:Class.skos:example: - An object *participates in* an event. - An object *has part* another object.
owl:Class.skos:scopeNote: - An *aircraft* is an object. - An *ATC descent procedure* is an object (formal regulation) that describes the course of a descent operation/process (event).

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Quantity
owl:Class.skos:definition: A «quantity» represents a substance sortal whose instances are quantities. Examples are those stuff universals that are typically referred in natural language by mass general terms (e.g., Gold, Water, Sand, Clay).

owl:Axiom.owl:annotatedTarget: A «quantity» represents a substance sortal whose instances are quantities. Examples are those stuff universals that are typically referred in natural language by mass general terms (e.g., Gold, Water, Sand, Clay).

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Poddruh
Sub-kind
owl:Class.skos:definition: A subkind is a rigid, relationally independent restriction of a substance sortal that carries the principle of identity supplied by it. An example could be the subkind MalePerson of the kind Person. In general, the stereotype subkind can be omitted in conceptual models without loss of clarity.

owl:Axiom.owl:annotatedTarget: A subkind is a rigid, relationally independent restriction of a substance sortal that carries the principle of identity supplied by it. An example could be the subkind MalePerson of the kind Person. In general, the stereotype subkind can be omitted in conceptual models without loss of clarity.

owl:Class.terms:description: Substance Sortal is an abstract metaclass that represents the general properties of all substance sortals, i.e., rigid, relationally independent object universals that supply a principle of identity for their instances. Substance Sortal has no concrete syntax. Thus, symbolic representations are defined by each of its concrete subclasses.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Substance sortal

owl:Axiom.owl:annotatedTarget: Substance Sortal is an abstract metaclass that represents the general properties of all substance sortals, i.e., rigid, relationally independent object universals that supply a principle of identity for their instances. Substance Sortal has no concrete syntax. Thus, symbolic representations are defined by each of its concrete subclasses.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Trope
Závislý endurant
owl:Class.skos:definition: Trope is a property of some object/event or another trope. The trope CANNOT exist without the object/event it inheres in.
owl:Class.skos:example:
We say that:
A trope *inheres in* an object.
owl:Class.skos:scopeNote: Examples include: - *function* of a VOR beacon (property of an object), - *availability* of VOR beacon function (property of a property), - *efficiency* of a rescue operation (property of an event)

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Typ
Type
owl:Class.skos:definition: A type is a class instances of which are all types of all levels. Type and Individual form a partition on the Entity class.
